Award.AwardTitle: Support for Young Researchers to attend the 2014 Intelligent Tutoring Systems Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States has historically been the global leader in the field of Intelligent Tutoring Systems, or ways to use computerized artificial intelligence to enhance teaching and learning in contexts ranging from children learning math in school, to soldiers learning highly technical jobs in the US military. The preeminent conference in this field is the ITS conference; at this conference the latest research is presented and practitioners learn the state of the art techniques that allow creation of these important educational technologies.

This proposal would support seven Ph.D. students, selected through a competitive process, to attend the conference, present their work, and receive additional mentoring outside of their dissertation committees. The intellectual merit of the work rests on the studies the graduate students submit to be considered for participation in the early career track of the conference; this work is then enhanced by guidance from world-class mentors who meet with the students in a structured format to improve their research. The broader impact includes the career impact on the seven selected students, especially since promising graduate students whose advisors may not have funding to send them to the conference can still be included, and their work can be showcased and improved. Possible long-term broader impacts include building the field of ITS researchers and improving the quality of tutoring systems, and thus eventually, improving the quality of education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded seven graduate student researchers to attend the Intelligent Tutoring Systems Conference in Hawaii, June 2014. ITS conferences have been run for 24 years and provide a unique environment in which researchers and practitioners exchange ideas, theories, experiments, techniques, applications and evaluations of initiatives supporting new developments relevant for the future. This ITS 2014 conference offered a professional opportunity for Young Researchers from all over the world to present cutting-edge research from the fields of Artificial Intelligence (AI), computer science, cognitive and learning sciences, psychology, and educational technology. Graduate students who were selected to receive NSF funds enjoyed several special sessions to present their research ideas and to receive feedback from researchers in the ITS community. This activity supports the mission of NSF and other granting agencies to train more advanced professionals in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).

This funding from NSF supported 7 advanced doctoral students to attend the 5-day conference and associated tutorials and workshops associated with the 12th International Conference on Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) held in Honolulu, Hawaii, from June 5-9, 2014. The Young Researchers’ Track (YRT) provided a forum in which PhD students presented and discussed their work during its early stages, met peers with related interests, and worked with more senior members of the field (mentors). The program was open to all PhD students and invited submissions of papers with advisors or collaborators. The students profited from their experience at the conferences as indicated in their written comments to the YRT Committee.

Summaries for all accepted proposals were published in the conference proceedings and made available on-line through the conference website. Students presented their research to the larger community, spoke individually with leaders in the field and generally received strong support by articulating their research and receiving feedback. Many of these conversations continued later during the year and many mentors have been included on student dissertation committees. NSF funding supported students to become involved in the conference and activities in subsequent years as members of the ITS community. Students had access to various ITS resources provided to the international members. More young researchers will be actively integrated with the community of ITS researchers as a result of this award.
